div1.note: Hon: W. Hunter Asst. Secty. of State Washington D.C.
div1.p: Sir I have the honor of acknowledge the receipt of your dispatch No. 10, in regard to agents appointed by the until appnored by the Hon: Secty. of State, it was and still is with the intention of promoting Am: Commerce in this part of the world, beside putting a stop to rimauray seamen, for abuse received on board Am: Whalers: and while enforcing the N. S. Laur over this jurisdiction, to give pr justice to seamen, masters or officers. "Massamedes" will in a few years become important large fields of wheat, corn, sugar cane, and cottau are now in cultivation.

The Portuguese Govt. is organizing small colonies all over that district, the Biers in "Whellah" and "Humpata" are cutting conformity with the Portuguese, a route from the interior; so that these crops and the reuslt of their bounty, such as, Hidis Ivory ostrich features, can be carried to Massamedes; these colonies as well as the Baire; -and iveu the natives of the interior who seem to follow now the
example of the Bvers -well snow wank farming implements; and I do not know if any to the compared with those of the U. S. for simplicity, donability and cheapness. The merchants and large land builders will need also steam mills, and other machinery for making rum, sugar, grinding corn and wheats cleaning and pressing cattou jnja Am. Wahlers seem to make their head quarters noer at that place, "although the last inducements have been granted to them by the Portuguese going." at Loauda.

I understand that non Whalers men there during last two months. Now the "Eliza Adams" three learn a aivay and from the "Alice Knowles" a man was discharged by reason of sickness; these seamen have been sent to me from Messamedes at a great expense, and I find myself compelled to keep them until I am able to forward them to Sautrago Capesendes by mail steaming, which only takes the occasionally more as a javor, although I pay to the Capt. L 5.0.0, for each man.

Mr. J.L. Fores that I appointed until appored by the Hon: Sectry. of State is the Largest merchant of Messamedes, a young
man, full of energy, and ambitious to promote the commerce and development of Massamedes.

It is only upon close enquiry, as to his capacity, integrity, capability jajs that I appointed him. If the State Dept. has any objections to these appointments, I will notify them at once as not having been accop by this State Dept.

I have never seen either of the gentlemen of Anclry, Bengnella or Massamedes; but I am confident that an agent is needed at Massamedes for the interest of Am: Commerce and protection of Am: Seamen and others visiting that port.
I have the honor to be Sir Your obedient servant
